description: A video of a 'gentle' caesarean birth has prompted a Melbourne doula to push for change in the way the procedure is performed. Angela Gallo issued a call to arms after watching the moving clip.
title: Melbourne doula shares Instagram video of caesarean birth
title_page: Melbourne doula shares Instagram video of caesarean birth | Daily Mail Online
text:
A 'gentle' cesarean video has prompted an Melbourne doula to push for change in the way the procedure is performed.
Angela Gallo shared the video with her 25,000 Instagram followers on Tuesday and told them the caption 'made her weep'.
The black and white clip shows a baby in the 'podalica position' - where it is either sitting or due to come out bottom first instead of head first - and his 'gentle', slow, c-section delivery.
Scroll down for video
Melbourne doula Angela Gallo (pictured) shared the black and white clip with her 25,000 Instagram followers as an example of the way she believes caesareans should be performed
The clip showed the gentle removal of each limb as the baby was slowly pulled from the womb by the hands of the doctors
The video, which was taken at a hospital in Venezuela, was originally posted by obstetrician Dr Jham Frank Lugo, who wrote a detailed caption on what it was that made the delivery so special.
'We can see in this video a birth, respectful and careful with... a vigilance that ensures the safety of the baby and the mother,' a translation of his original caption read.
'With patience, listening to the music that the parents choose for this moment, and with the support of the father and their doula, the mother can be held throughout the whole process.
'After birth the baby can immediately be with his mother. Delayed cord clamping. Early attachment; in union doctor and patient can achieve a birth that is respectful.'
The clip showed the gentle removal of each limb as the baby was slowly pulled from the womb by the hands of the doctors.
Ms Gallo wrote she could 'feel the connection' between everyone in the room, before issuing a call to arms.
Slowly but surely: The clip shows doctors slowly easing the baby boy out of the womb limb by limb using their hands
'Know better, ask for better': Ms Gallo said all c-sections could be performed in this manner, as opposed to a more 'clinical, rushed, hardlined' birth
'I wish this was available for everyone - please mamas, changes like this are entirely consumer driven,' she wrote.
'Know better, ask for better, set a better standard for birthing people worldwide.
'Birth does not need to be clinical, rushed hard lined and full of rough handling... let's make cesarean birth a special place because all birth deserves to be and feel beautiful for baby, mama and family too.'
